critters.name: White-tailed Deer
critters.summary: Common woodland browser often seen near fields and feeders.
critters.fact: White-tailed deer use their white tails to signal danger by flashing them like a warning flag.

critters.name: Black Bear
critters.summary: Largest forest mammal in Michigan woodlands.
critters.fact: Black bears can run up to 30 miles per hour despite their bulky size!

critters.name: Coyote
critters.summary: Adaptable predator common in rural areas.
critters.fact: Coyotes communicate using howls, yips, and barks to coordinate with their pack and mark territory.

critters.name: Red Fox
critters.summary: Solitary hunter active in open woods and fields.
critters.fact: Red foxes use their fluffy tails for balance and warmth during cold weather.

critters.name: Gray Fox
critters.summary: Smaller fox species able to climb trees.
critters.fact: Gray foxes are unique for their ability to climb trees, unlike most other North American foxes.

critters.name: Bobcat
critters.fact: Bobcats have tufted ears and can leap up to 10 feet to catch prey!

critters.name: Porcupine
critters.fact: Porcupines have sharp quills that detach easily to protect them from predators.

critters.name: Beaver
critters.fact: Beavers build dams to create ponds, protecting their homes from predators and providing easy access to food.

critters.name: Muskrat
critters.summary: Small aquatic rodent near ponds and streams.
critters.fact: Muskrats build underwater lodges using plants, with tunnels that keep them safe from predators above water!

critters.name: Mink
critters.fact: Minks are semi-aquatic mammals known for their sleek fur and excellent swimming skills.

critters.name: Fisher
critters.fact: Fishers are skilled climbers and use trees to hunt their prey, including porcupines!

critters.name: River Otter
critters.summary: Playful aquatic predator found near rivers.
critters.fact: River otters can hold their breath underwater for up to 8 minutes while hunting fish!

critters.name: Eastern Gray Squirrel
critters.fact: Eastern Gray Squirrels can find buried nuts using their amazing sense of smell under snow!

critters.name: American Red Squirrel
critters.fact: American Red Squirrels fiercely defend their food caches to survive harsh winters in North American forests.

critters.name: Chipmunk
critters.summary: Ground squirrel known for cheek pouches.
critters.fact: Chipmunks can gather and store thousands of seeds in cheek pouches for winter food.

critters.name: Snowshoe Hare
critters.summary: Forest rabbit with seasonal coat change.
critters.fact: Snowshoe hares change their fur color seasonally for camouflageâ€”brown in summer, white in winter!

critters.name: Eastern Cottontail
critters.fact: Eastern Cottontails can run up to 18 miles per hour to escape predators!

critters.name: Raccoon
critters.fact: Raccoons have highly sensitive front paws, helping them identify food by touch almost like human hands!

critters.name: Opossum
critters.fact: Opossums are immune to snake venom, making them natural predators of venomous snakes like rattlesnakes!

critters.name: Striped Skunk
critters.summary: Night forager known for defensive spray.
critters.fact: Striped skunks can spray a smelly liquid up to 10 feet to deter predators.

critters.name: Flying Squirrel
critters.fact: Flying squirrels glide using a special skin flap called a patagium between their front and back legs.

critters.name: Little Brown Bat
critters.fact: Little Brown Bats use echolocation to hunt insects, emitting high-pitched sounds inaudible to humans.

critters.name: Big Brown Bat
critters.fact: Big Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects, helping control pest populations naturally!

critters.name: Barred Owl
critters.summary: Woodland owl known for 'who cooks for you' call.
critters.fact: Barred Owls hoot with a distinctive â€œWho cooks for you? Who cooks for you all?â€ call.

critters.name: Great Horned Owl
critters.fact: Great Horned Owls have incredible night vision and silent flight for hunting in the dark!

critters.name: Blue Jay
critters.summary: Bold feeder visitor with loud calls.
critters.fact: Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away predators or other birds from their territory!

critters.name: Northern Cardinal
critters.fact: Northern Cardinals are one of the few birds where males and females both sing beautifully.

critters.name: Black-capped Chickadee
critters.fact: Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of food hiding spots using their excellent spatial memory!

critters.name: Tufted Titmouse
critters.fact: Tufted Titmice can remember thousands of hidden seeds, helping them survive winterâ€™s cold months.

critters.name: White-breasted Nuthatch
critters.summary: Tree climber often moving headfirst down bark.
critters.fact: White-breasted Nuthatches can climb headfirst down tree trunks to find hidden insects!

critters.name: Downy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Downy Woodpeckers use their tiny beaks to drum on trees, communicating and searching for insects.

critters.name: Hairy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Hairy Woodpeckers have a bill nearly as long as their head, perfect for drilling into trees!

critters.name: Pileated Woodpecker
critters.fact: Pileated Woodpeckers create large rectangular holes to find ants and insects in dead trees.

critters.name: Red-bellied Woodpecker
critters.fact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers use their strong beaks to drill into trees for insects and sap.

critters.name: Mourning Dove
critters.fact: Mourning Doves can eat up to 6,000 seeds a day with their strong, quick beaks!

critters.name: American Goldfinch
critters.fact: American Goldfinches molt twice yearly, showing bright yellow plumage only during spring and summer.

critters.name: Dark-eyed Junco
critters.fact: Dark-eyed Juncos are often called "snowbirds" because they appear in winter across much of North America.

critters.name: House Finch
critters.fact: House Finches are known for their cheerful songs, which males use to attract mates and defend territory.

critters.name: Purple Finch
critters.fact: Purple Finches have a sweet, raspberry-like song that brightens North American forests during spring!

critters.name: Wild Turkey
critters.summary: Large ground bird common in Michigan.
critters.fact: Wild turkeys can run up to 20 miles per hour and fly short distances to escape danger!

critters.name: Ruffed Grouse
critters.summary: Forest bird known for drumming display.
critters.fact: Ruffed Grouse create a unique drumming sound by beating their wings to attract mates.

critters.name: Sandhill Crane
critters.summary: Tall wetland bird with loud call.
critters.fact: Sandhill Cranes perform rhythmic dances to communicate and strengthen pair bonds during mating season!

critters.name: American Crow
critters.fact: American Crows use tools, like sticks, to help them find and catch insects for food.

critters.name: Common Raven
critters.fact: Common Ravens can mimic human speech and other sounds, showing impressive vocal intelligence in the wild!

critters.name: Red-tailed Hawk
critters.fact: Red-tailed Hawks use their sharp vision to spot prey from over a mile away in the wild!

critters.name: Cooperâ€™s Hawk
critters.fact: Cooperâ€™s Hawks are skilled hunters, often catching birds mid-flight with incredible speed and agility!

critters.name: Mallard Duck
critters.fact: Mallard ducks dabble in water, tipping forward to feed on plants and insects beneath the surface.

critters.name: Wood Duck
critters.summary: Colorful duck nesting in tree cavities.
critters.fact: Wood Ducks nest in tree cavities, making them unique among North American waterfowl.

critters.name: Canada Goose
critters.fact: Canada Geese can fly over 1,500 miles during migration without stopping to rest!

critters.name: Great Blue Heron
critters.fact: Great Blue Herons can stand still for long periods, patiently hunting fish with their sharp beaks!

critters.name: Painted Turtle
critters.fact: Painted turtles can live over 30 years and absorb oxygen through their skin while underwater!

critters.name: Snapping Turtle
critters.fact: Snapping turtles can live over 30 years and have powerful jaws to snap quickly at prey or threats!

critters.name: Bluegill
critters.fact: Bluegill can breathe air using a special organ, helping them survive in low-oxygen waters!

critters.name: Largemouth Bass
critters.fact: Largemouth bass can grow over 2 feet long and use their big mouths to ambush prey!

critters.name: Yellow Perch
critters.fact: Yellow perch have sharp spines on their fins to help protect them from predators in the wild!

critters.name: Northern Pike
critters.fact: Northern Pike can grow over 4 feet long and use ambush tactics to catch prey swiftly!

critters.name: Spring Peeper
critters.summary: Tiny frog with loud spring calls.
critters.fact: Spring Peepers are tiny frogs known for their loud, distinctive peeping calls during early spring nights.

critters.name: American Bullfrog
critters.fact: American Bullfrogs can grow up to 8 inches long, making them some of the largest frogs in North America!

critters.name: Green Frog
critters.fact: Green frogs can jump over 4 feet, using powerful back legs to escape predators swiftly.

critters.name: Leopard Frog
critters.fact: Leopard frogs can jump over 20 times their body length to escape predators quickly!

critters.name: Garter Snake
critters.fact: Garter snakes can swim and often live near water, making them excellent swimmers in the wild!

critters.name: Water Snake
critters.fact: Water snakes can breathe underwater by holding their breath up to an hour while hunting fish.

critters.name: Eastern Milk Snake
critters.fact: Eastern Milk Snakes mimic venomous coral snakes with their colorful patterns to avoid predators.

critters.name: Monarch Butterfly
critters.fact: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles between Canada and Mexico each year!

critters.name: Swallowtail Butterfly
critters.fact: Swallowtail butterflies have tail-like wings that mimic a swallowâ€™s tail to confuse predators!

critters.name: Dragonfly
critters.fact: Dragonflies can fly in six directions: up, down, forward, backward, and side to side!

critters.name: Damselfly
critters.fact: Damselflies fold their wings over their bodies, unlike dragonflies that keep wings spread out.

critters.name: Firefly
critters.fact: Fireflies use light to communicate, attracting mates with unique flashing patterns in the dark.

critters.name: Honeybee
critters.fact: Honeybees communicate by dancing to share directions to the best flowers with their hive mates!

critters.name: Bumblebee
critters.fact: Bumblebees have fuzzy bodies that help them collect pollen and stay warm during cool weather.

critters.name: Grasshopper
critters.fact: Grasshoppers have powerful hind legs that let them jump over 20 times their body length!
